ground_truth: The study is cluttered with books, and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk, studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just studying it; he is copying it into his own notebook, sketching with his hand and holding up one finger. The study door is just closing, Indy closing it behind him, just as Herman comes through the front door, still playing the trumpet. Indy reaches for the trumpet, pulling it from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face. Herman means the sheriff, who now enters the house. Indy shows the Cross, more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point, and the sheriff takes it casually. Fedora enters the house, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and politely removes his hat, holding it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots, and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on Indy's head, a show of respect and admiration for the boy. The hat blocks Indy's face, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, years older now, removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea, with thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums, Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The research is messy with volumes, and Professor Henry Jones is engrossed at his table, examining a very old scroll tome that lies open on the table. The leaf shows a gorgeously illustrated depiction of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a sequence of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just examining it; he is duplicating it into his own journal, sketching with his hand and holding up one digit. The study door is just closing, Indy shutting it behind him, just as Herman enters the front door, still playing the cornet. Indy reaches for the cornet, pulling it from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's visage. Herman means the marshal, who now enters the dwelling. Indy shows the Reliquary, more or less handing it to the marshal to make his point, and the marshal takes it nonchalantly. Fedora enters the dwelling, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and courteously removes his hat, holding it in his hand. The marshal and Fedora are in partnership, and the marshal hands the Reliquary to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. He holds the hat by the crown and places it on Indy's head, a show of respect and admiration for the youth. The hat blocks Indy's visage, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up, we see the visage of a fully grown Indiana Jones, who is punched in the visage while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, years older now, removes the Reliquary of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and rain pours down in the middle of a turbulent squall at sea, with thirty-foot surges crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese mariners, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel barrels, Indy uses the mariners as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clasp on the metal bands that hold the barrels together. Indy jabs his elbows into the mariners' abdomens and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of surges crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the reliquary back from Panama Hat, but a mariner delivers a powerful blow to Indy's visage, sending the reliquary flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books, and the desk is where Professor Henry Jones is absorbed, studying a very ancient parchment volume that is lying open. A beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a series of Roman numerals, is shown by the page. He is not just studying it; it is being copied by him into his own notebook, as he sketches with his hand and holds up one finger. The study door is just closing, being closed by Indy behind him, just as the front door is opened by Herman, still playing the trumpet. The trumpet is reached for by Indy, and it is pulled from Herman's mouth, but right into Indy's face is where Herman continues to spit. Herman means the sheriff, who now enters the house. The Cross is shown by Indy, more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point, and it is taken casually by the sheriff. The house is entered by Fedora, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and the hat is politely removed by him, as he holds it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots, and Fedora is handed the Cross by the sheriff. Roscoe reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. The hat is held by the crown, and it is put on Indy's head by Fedora, a show of respect and admiration for the boy. Indy's face is blocked by the hat, and the screen is filled by the brim. As the brim tilts up, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is punched in the face while two Portuguese sailors pin his arms behind his back. The Cross of Coronado is removed from Indy's belt by the Man in the Panama Hat, who is now years older. It's night, and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea, with thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who pin Indy's arms behind his back, propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As a bundle of fuel drums is passed, the sailors are used as leverage by Indy to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. His elbows are jabbed into the sailors' stomachs by Indy, and he rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. The force of waves crashing on the deck is withstood by Indy, and he makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. The cross is taken back from Panama Hat by Indy, but a powerful blow is delivered by a sailor to Indy's face, sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books, and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk, examining an ancient parchment volume open before him. The page displays a beautifully illuminated image resembling a stained-glass window with Roman numerals. The Professor is not just examining it; he is copying it into his notebook, sketching with one hand and holding up a finger. Indy closes the study door as Herman enters, still playing the trumpet. Indy grabs the trumpet from Herman, who spits into Indy's face. Herman means the sheriff, who enters the house. Indy shows the Cross to the sheriff, who takes it casually. Fedora enters with Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, politely removing his hat. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots, and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe takes it from Fedora and runs out. Fedora stays, speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way, placing his hat on Indy's head as a sign of respect. The hat blocks Indy's face, and as the brim tilts up, we see a grown Indiana Jones, punched in the face with his arms pinned. The Man in the Panama Hat, now older, removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and rain pours during a violent storm at sea, with thirty-foot waves crashing. Two Portuguese sailors pin Indy's arms and propel him toward the rail. Passing fuel drums, Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick open the clamp on the metal bands. He elbows the sailors and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who hurries to the bridge ladder. Indy withstands crashing waves and reaches Panama Hat, retrieving the cross, but a sailor punches Indy, sending the cross skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books, and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk, studying an ancient parchment with a stained-glass window illustration and Roman numerals. He copies it into his notebook, sketching with one hand. Indy closes the study door as Herman enters, playing the trumpet. Indy grabs the trumpet, but Herman spits in his face. The sheriff enters, and Indy shows him the Cross, which the sheriff casually hands to Fedora, who enters with Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed. Fedora removes his hat, and Roscoe takes the Cross and runs out. Fedora speaks to Indy, placing his hat on Indy's head as a sign of respect. The brim tilts up, revealing a grown Indiana Jones, who is punched while restrained. The Man in the Panama Hat, older now, takes the Cross from Indy's belt. Amid a storm at sea, two Portuguese sailors pin Indy's arms and propel him across the deck. Indy uses them to break open fuel drums, elbows them, and rushes toward Panama Hat, who climbs a ladder. Indy retrieves the Cross, but a sailor punches him, sending the Cross skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The study is a space filled to the brim with an overwhelming number of books, creating a cluttered and somewhat chaotic atmosphere. Professor Henry Jones is deeply engrossed at his desk, where he is intently examining a very ancient and fragile parchment volume that lies open before him. The page he is focused on displays a beautifully illuminated picture, which appears to be a depiction of a stained-glass window, intricately incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not merely studying this image; he is meticulously copying it into his own notebook, sketching with one hand while holding up a finger for precision. Meanwhile, the study door is just closing, with Indy having closed it behind him, precisely at the moment when Herman enters through the front door, still energetically playing the trumpet. Indy reaches out for the trumpet, pulling it away from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit, inadvertently right into Indy's face. Herman is referring to the sheriff, who now makes his entrance into the house. Indy presents the Cross, more or less handing it over to the sheriff to emphasize his point, and the sheriff accepts it with a casual demeanor. Fedora enters the house next, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and he politely removes his hat, holding it respectfully in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are clearly in cahoots, and the sheriff hands the Cross over to Fedora. Roscoe then reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and swiftly runs out the door. Fedora lingers behind for a moment, turning to speak to Indy in an ironic, man-to-man manner. He holds the hat by the crown and places it on Indy's head, a gesture of respect and admiration for the young boy. The hat obscures Indy's face, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts upward, we transition to see the face of a fully grown Indiana Jones, who is being punched in the face while his arms are restrained behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, now years older, removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It is nighttime, and rain pours down relentlessly in the midst of a violent storm at sea, with massive thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, propel him across the deck toward the rail. As they pass by a bundle of fuel drums, Indy cleverly uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who, seeing Indy approaching, hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of the waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy manages to take the cross back from Panama Hat, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, causing the cross to fly out of his grip and skitter across the deck.

Expanded (~130%, 374 words):

The study is a space that is filled to the brim with an overwhelming number of books, creating a cluttered and somewhat chaotic atmosphere. Professor Henry Jones finds himself deeply engrossed at his desk, where he is intently examining a very ancient and incredibly fragile parchment volume that lies open before him. The page upon which his attention is focused displays a beautifully illuminated picture, which appears to be a depiction of a stained-glass window, intricately incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not merely studying this image; he is meticulously copying it into his own notebook, sketching carefully with one hand while simultaneously holding up a finger for precision. Meanwhile, the study door is just closing, with Indy having closed it behind him, precisely at the moment when Herman makes his entrance through the front door, still energetically playing the trumpet. Indy swiftly reaches out for the trumpet, pulling it away from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit, inadvertently right into Indy's face. Herman is referring to the sheriff, who now makes his dramatic entrance into the house. Indy presents the Cross, more or less handing it over to the sheriff to emphasize his point, and the sheriff accepts it with a casual, nonchalant demeanor. Fedora enters the house next, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and he politely removes his hat, holding it respectfully in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are clearly in cahoots, and the sheriff hands the Cross over to Fedora. Roscoe then reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and swiftly runs out the door. Fedora lingers behind for a moment, turning to speak to Indy in an ironic, man-to-man manner. He holds the hat by the crown and places it on Indy's head, a gesture of respect and admiration for the young boy. The hat obscures Indy's face, and the brim fills the entire screen. As the brim tilts upward, we transition to see the face of a fully grown Indiana Jones, who is being punched in the face while his arms are restrained behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, now years older, removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It is nighttime, and rain pours down relentlessly in the midst of a violent storm at sea, with massive thirty-foot waves crashing forcefully across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned tightly behind his back, propel him across the deck toward the rail. As they pass by a bundle of fuel drums, Indy cleverly uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who, seeing Indy approaching, hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of the waves crashing heavily on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy manages to take the cross back from Panama Hat, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, causing the cross to fly out of his grip and skitter rapidly across the deck.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The study is filled with an overwhelming number of books, creating a cluttered environment where Professor Henry Jones is deeply engrossed at his desk. He is intently examining a very ancient parchment volume that lies open before him, its pages revealing a beautifully illuminated picture that resembles a stained-glass window, intricately incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not merely observing this image; he is actively engaged in the process of copying it into his own notebook. With focused precision, he sketches the details with his hand, occasionally pausing to hold up one finger as if to measure or compare. Meanwhile, the study door is in motion, just closing as Indy steps inside, having closed it behind him. At the same moment, Herman enters through the front door, energetically playing the trumpet. Indy, with a swift motion, reaches for the trumpet and pulls it from Herman's mouth, but Herman, undeterred, continues to spit, inadvertently directing it right into Indy's face. Herman's actions are interrupted by the arrival of the sheriff, who now enters the house. Indy, seeking to make a point, presents the Cross, more or less handing it to the sheriff, who accepts it with a casual demeanor. Fedora then enters the house, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and with a gesture of politeness, he removes his hat, holding it respectfully in his hand. It becomes evident that the sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots, as the sheriff hands the Cross over to Fedora. Roscoe, seizing the opportunity, reaches in, takes the Cross from Fedora, and swiftly runs out the door. Fedora lingers for a moment, turning to speak to Indy in an ironic, man-to-man manner. In a gesture of respect and admiration for the boy, he holds the hat by the crown and places it on Indy's head. The hat's brim obscures Indy's face, filling the screen entirely. As the brim tilts upward, the scene transitions to reveal the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is abruptly punched in the face while his arms are restrained behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, now years older, steps forward and removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. The setting shifts to night, where a violent storm rages at sea, with rain pouring down and thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. Two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, forcefully propel him across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums, Indy cleverly uses the sailors as leverage, kicking up his feet to break open the clamp on the metal bands that secure the drums together. With a swift motion, Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs, freeing himself and rushing toward the Man in the Panama Hat. Sensing Indy's approach, Panama Hat hastens toward the ladder leading up to the bridge. Indy, undeterred by the force of the waves crashing on the deck, perseveres and reaches the ladder where Panama Hat is climbing. In a daring move, Indy retrieves the cross from Panama Hat, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, causing the cross to fly out of his grip and skitter across the deck.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books as Professor Henry Jones is deeply engrossed in copying an ancient parchment's illuminated picture into his notebook. Indy enters, closing the door behind him, just as Herman arrives playing the trumpet. Indy pulls the trumpet away, but Herman spits in his face, signaling the sheriff's arrival. Indy presents the Cross to the sheriff, who casually hands it to Fedora, who enters with Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed. Roscoe takes the Cross and runs out, while Fedora, showing respect, places his hat on Indy's head. The brim obscures Indy's face, transitioning to a grown Indiana Jones being punched while restrained. The Man in the Panama Hat, now older, takes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt amid a storm at sea. Indy, using the sailors restraining him, breaks free by kicking open fuel drum clamps, then elbows the sailors and charges at Panama Hat. Despite the crashing waves, Indy reaches Panama Hat on the ladder, retrieves the Cross, but loses it again when a sailor strikes him, sending it skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books, and Professor Henry Jones, a renowned archaeologist with a passion for ancient texts, is absorbed at his desk, studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stained-glass window, a craft perfected in medieval Europe, incorporating a series of Roman numerals, likely used for dating or symbolic purposes. The Professor is not just studying it; he is copying it into his own notebook, sketching with his hand and holding up one finger to help maintain his place in the book. The study door is just closing, Indy closing it behind him, just as Herman comes through the front door, still playing the trumpet, an instrument known for its distinctive, brassy sound. Indy reaches for the trumpet, pulling it from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face, demonstrating a playful yet annoying gesture. Herman means the sheriff, who now enters the house. Indy shows the Cross of Coronado, a legendary artifact said to have been owned by the explorer Francisco Vásquez de Coronado, more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point, and the sheriff takes it casually. Fedora enters the house, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, a group that resembles a motley crew from an old Western film, and politely removes his hat, holding it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots, collaborating in their schemes, and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way that suggests a grudging respect. He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on Indy's head, a show of respect and admiration for the boy. The hat blocks Indy's face, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, named for the distinctive wide-brimmed straw hat often associated with tropical climates, years older now, removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea, where waves can easily reach towering heights, with thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, reflect the historical significance of Portugal's maritime heritage, propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums, Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge, a term for the ship's command center. Indy withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stainedglass window incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just studying it he is copying it into his own notebook sketching with his hand and holding up one finger. The study door is just closing Indy closing it behind him just as Herman comes through the front door still playing the trumpet. Indy reaches for the trumpet pulling it from Herman's mouth but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face. Herman means the sheriff who now enters the house. Indy shows the Cross more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point and the sheriff takes it casually. Fedora enters the house followed by Roscoe Rough Rider and Halfbreed and politely removes his hat holding it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in takes it from Fedora and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic mantoman way. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on Indy's head a show of respect and admiration for the boy. The hat blocks Indy's face and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up we see the face of a fullgrown Indiana Jones who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat years older now removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It is night and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea with thirtyfoot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat. but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stainedglass window incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just studying it he is copying it into his own notebook sketching with his hand and holding up one finger. The study door is just closing Indy closing it behind him just as Herman comes through the front door still playing the trumpet. Indy reaches for the trumpet pulling it from Herman's mouth but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face. Herman means the sheriff who now enters the house. Indy shows the Cross more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point and the sheriff takes it casually. Fedora enters the house followed by Roscoe Rough Rider and Halfbreed and politely removes his hat holding it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in takes it from Fedora and runs out the door. Fedora remains behind for a moment turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic mantoman way. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on Indy's head a show of respect and admiration for the boy. The hat blocks Indy's face and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up we see the face of a fullgrown Indiana Jones who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat years older now removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It is night and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea with thirtyfoot waves crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat. but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stainedglass window incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just studying it he is copying it into his own notebook sketching with his hand and holding up one finger. Indy reaches for the trumpet pulling it from Herman's mouth but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face. Herman means the sheriff who now enters the house. test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stainedglass window incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just studying it he is copying it into his own notebook sketching with his hand and holding up one finger. Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat. but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books, and the librarian is absorbed at the desk, studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The librarian is not just studying it; the cat is copying it into its own notebook, sketching with its paw and holding up one finger. The study door is just closing, the dog closing it behind him, just as the postman comes through the front door, still playing the trumpet. The dog reaches for the trumpet, pulling it from the postman's mouth, but the postman continues to spit right into the dog's face. The postman means the judge, who now enters the house. The dog shows the Cross, more or less handing it to the judge to make his point, and the judge takes it casually. The chef enters the house, followed by the painter, the gardener, and the baker, and politely removes his hat, holding it in his hand. The judge and the chef are in cahoots, and the judge hands the Cross to the chef. The painter reaches in, takes it from the chef, and runs out the door. The chef remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to the dog in an ironic man-to-man way. He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on the dog's head, a show of respect and admiration for the dog. The hat blocks the dog's face, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim tilts up, we see the face of a full-grown detective, who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The jazz musician, years older now, removes the Cross of Coronado from the detective's belt. It's night, and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea, with thirty-foot waves crashing across the deck. The two chefs, who have the detective's arms pinned behind his back, propel the detective across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums, the detective uses the chefs as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. The detective jabs his elbows into the chefs' stomachs and rushes toward the jazz musician, who sees the detective coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. The detective withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where the jazz musician is climbing the ladder. The detective takes the cross back from the jazz musician, but a carpenter delivers a powerful blow to the detective's face, sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with pottery, and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his counter, studying a very ancient wall tapestry that lies open on the counter. The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a marble statue, incorporating a series of Arabic numerals. The Professor is not just studying it; he is copying it into his own journal, sketching with his hand and holding up one spoon. The study door is just closing, Indy closing it behind him, just as Herman comes through the garden entrance, still playing the saxophone. Indy reaches for the saxophone, pulling it from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face. Herman means the grocer, who now enters the conservatory. Indy shows the Amulet, more or less handing it to the grocer to make his point, and the grocer takes it casually. Fedora enters the conservatory, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and politely removes his scarf, holding it in his hand. The grocer and Fedora are in cahoots, and the grocer hands the Amulet to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in, takes it from Fedora, and runs out the gate. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. He holds the scarf by the fringe and puts it on Indy's head, a show of respect and admiration for the boy. The scarf blocks Indy's face, and the edge fills the screen. As the edge tilts up, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Sombrero, years older now, removes the Amulet of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and snow pours down in the middle of a violent blizzard at sea, with thirty-foot icebergs crashing across the deck. The two Portuguese masons, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, propel Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of flour sacks, Indy uses the masons as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the latch on the leather straps that hold the sacks together. Indy jabs his elbows into the masons' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Sombrero, who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the crow's nest. Indy withstands the force of icebergs crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Sombrero is climbing the ladder. Indy takes the amulet back from Sombrero, but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face, sending the amulet flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The study is filled with books, and Professor Henry Jones is focused at his desk, doodling a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk. The page displays a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Professor is not just doodling it; he is tossing it into his own notebook, scribbling with his hand and waving one finger. The study door is just slamming shut, Indy slamming it behind him, as Herman bursts through the front door, still juggling the trumpet. Indy reaches for the trumpet, yanking it from Herman's mouth, but Herman continues to glare right into Indy's face. Herman represents the sheriff, who now trips into the house. Indy flaunts the Cross, more or less tossing it to the sheriff to make his point, and the sheriff catches it nonchalantly. Fedora bursts into the house, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and politely flings his hat, holding it in his hand. The sheriff and Fedora are in collusion, and the sheriff flips the Cross to Fedora. Roscoe sneaks in, snatches it from Fedora, and darts out the door. Fedora lingers behind for a moment, spinning and joking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. He twirls the hat by the crown and pops it on Indy's head, a gesture of respect and admiration for the boy. The hat covers Indy's face, and the brim fills the screen. As the brim bounces up, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is shoved in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back. The Man in the Panama Hat, years older now, swipes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt. It's night, and lightning crackles down in the middle of a violent storm at sea, with thirty-foot waves cascading across the deck. The two Portuguese sailors, who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back, yank Indy across the deck toward the rail. As they pass a bundle of fuel drums, Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and dismantle the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together. Indy nudges his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and dashes toward the Man in the Panama Hat, who notices Indy approaching and retreats toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge. Indy endures the force of waves crashing on the deck and navigates his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder. Indy snatches the cross back from Panama Hat, but a sailor lands a hefty blow to Indy's face, sending the cross sailing out of his grip and skittering across the deck.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The kitchen is cluttered with maps, and Chef Betty Smith is absorbed at her counter, examining a very ancient pottery shard that lies open on the counter. The fragment shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a marble statue, incorporating a series of hieroglyphics. The Chef is not just examining it; she is copying it into her own recipe book, sketching with her whisk and holding up one spoon. The kitchen door is just closing, Alex closing it behind them, just as Martin comes through the back gate, still swinging the tennis racket. Alex reaches for the tennis racket, pulling it from Martin's hand, but Martin continues to swing right into Alex's elbow. Martin means the gardener, who now enters the patio. Alex shows the Compass, more or less handing it to the gardener to make their point, and the gardener takes it casually. Bowler Hat enters the patio, followed by Maverick, Lone Star, and Sidekick, and politely removes their sunglasses, holding them in their hand. The gardener and Bowler Hat are in cahoots, and the gardener hands the Compass to Bowler Hat. Maverick reaches in, takes it from Bowler Hat, and runs out the gate. Bowler Hat remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Alex in an ironic person-to-person way. They hold the sunglasses by the arm and put them on Alex's head, a show of respect and admiration for the kid. The sunglasses block Alex's face, and the lenses fill the screen. As the lenses tilt up, we see the face of a full-grown Jackie Barnes, who is punched in the face while their legs are pinned behind their back. The Woman in the Sun Hat, years older now, removes the Compass of Delphi from Jackie's belt. It's dusk, and snow pours down in the middle of a violent blizzard on land, with thirty-foot trees crashing across the ground. The two Spanish carpenters, who have Jackie's legs pinned behind their back, propel Jackie across the ground toward the fence. As they pass a bundle of timber logs, Jackie uses the carpenters as leverage to kick up their feet and break open the clamp on the wooden beams that hold the logs together. Jackie jabs their knees into the carpenters' backs and rushes toward the Woman in the Sun Hat, who sees Jackie coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the roof. Jackie withstands the force of trees crashing on the ground and makes their way to where Sun Hat is climbing the ladder. Jackie takes the compass back from Sun Hat, but a carpenter delivers a powerful blow to Jackie's face, sending the compass flying out of their grip and skittering across the ground.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The veranda is cluttered with magazines, and Chef Elise Stone is fixated at her table, knitting a very ancient silk scarf that lies unfolded on the table. The fabric shows a beautifully embroidered image of what might be a stained-glass window, incorporating a series of Roman numerals. The Chef is not just knitting it; she is painting it into her own scrapbook, tracing with her hand and holding up one finger. The veranda curtain is just closing, Jamie closing it behind her, just as Max comes through the garden gate, still juggling the oranges. Jamie reaches for the oranges, plucking them from Max's hands, but Max continues to chatter right into Jamie's face. Max implies the marshal, who now enters the patio. Jamie displays the Trophy, more or less offering it to the marshal to make her point, and the marshal receives it casually. Fedora enters the patio, followed by Jasper, Trailblazer, and Thunderbird, and politely removes his scarf, holding it in his hand. The marshal and Fedora are in alliance, and the marshal passes the Trophy to Fedora. Jasper reaches in, snatches it from Fedora, and dashes out the gate. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Jamie in a sardonic friend-to-friend way. He holds the scarf by the tassel and drapes it over Jamie's shoulders, a show of respect and admiration for her. The scarf obscures Jamie's face, and the tassels fill the screen. As the tassels sway away, we see the face of a mature Jamie Stone, who is tapped on the shoulder while her legs are bound beneath her seat. The Woman in the Wide-Brimmed Hat, years older now, retrieves the Trophy of Triumph from Jamie's belt. It's night, and hail pelts down in the middle of a fierce storm in the forest, with huge branches crashing across the ground. The two Spanish woodcutters, who have Jamie's legs bound beneath her seat, propel Jamie across the ground toward the fence. As they pass a stack of timber logs, Jamie uses the woodcutters as leverage to swing up her feet and loosen the ropes on the metal bands that keep the logs together. Jamie elbows the woodcutters in the chests and dashes toward the Woman in the Wide-Brimmed Hat, who sees Jamie approaching and flees toward the staircase that leads up to the tower. Jamie endures the force of branches crashing on the ground and advances to where the Wide-Brimmed Hat is ascending the staircase. Jamie retrieves the trophy from the Wide-Brimmed Hat, but a woodcutter delivers a swift strike to Jamie's shoulder, sending the trophy tumbling from her grasp and sliding across the ground.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with plants, and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk, painting a very ancient ceramic vase that sits open on the desk. The surface shows a beautifully carved picture of what might be a mosaic tile, incorporating a series of Egyptian hieroglyphs. The Professor is not just painting it; he is photographing it into his own scrapbook, tracing with his foot and holding up two fingers. The study window is just opening, Indy opening it behind him, just as Herman comes in through the side window, still playing the saxophone. Indy reaches for the saxophone, removing it from Herman's hand, but Herman continues to whistle right into Indy's ear. Herman means the baker, who now enters the room. Indy shows the ring, more or less tossing it to the baker to make his point, and the baker catches it casually. Fedora enters the room, followed by Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, and politely removes his gloves, holding them in his pocket. The baker and Fedora are in cahoots, and the baker tosses the ring to Fedora. Roscoe reaches in, grabs it from Fedora, and slides out the window. Fedora remains behind for a moment, turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic man-to-man way. He holds the gloves by the cuff and places them on Indy's shoulders, a show of approval and admiration for the boy. The gloves cover Indy's shoulders, and the cuffs fill the screen. As the cuffs unfold, we see the face of a full-grown Indiana Jones, who is slapped in the face while his legs are tied in front of him. The Man in the Panama Shirt, years older now, removes the Ring of Coronado from Indy's pocket. It's day, and wind gusts across in the middle of a calm breeze at sea, with five-foot ripples lapping across the deck. The two Spanish chefs, who have Indy's legs tied in front of him, drag Indy across the deck toward the hatch. As they pass a pile of fruit crates, Indy uses the chefs as leverage to kick up his knees and rip open the latch on the wooden lids that hold the crates together. Indy jabs his toes into the chefs' shins and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Shirt, who sees Indy approaching and hurries toward the ramp that leads up to the helm. Indy withstands the force of wind brushing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Shirt is descending the ramp. Indy takes the ring back from Panama Shirt, but a chef delivers a gentle tap to Indy's shoulder, sending the ring rolling out of his grip and bouncing across the deck.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The garden is filled with cupcakes, and Chef Oliver Smith is engrossed on his bench, painting a very modern canvas masterpiece that sits resting on the table. The canvas displays a clumsily blurred sculpture of what might be a marble fountain, featuring a sequence of Chinese characters. The Chef is not just painting it; he is erasing it into his own scrapbook, coloring with his foot and sticking out one thumb. The garden gate is just swinging, Alex swinging it behind him, just as Gordon strolls through the front gate, still juggling the tambourine. Alex reaches for the tambourine, snatching it from Gordon's hand, but Gordon proceeds to tickle right into Alex's ear. Gordon represents the gardener, who now arrives at the garden. Alex displays the Coin, more or less tossing it to the gardener to illustrate his point, and the gardener catches it nonchalantly. Fedora arrives at the garden, followed by Timber, Slide Master, and Painted Horse, and cheerfully unbuttons his coat, clutching it in his arm. The gardener and Fedora are in league, and the gardener tosses the Coin to Fedora. Timber leans in, grabs it from Fedora, and skips out the gate. Fedora stays behind for a moment, spinning and chatting to Alex in a sarcastic buddy-to-buddy way. He holds the coat by the sleeve and drapes it on Alex's shoulder, a gesture of honor and appreciation for the boy. The coat hides Alex's ear, and the collar fills the screen. As the collar shifts up, we glimpse the ear of a grown-up Alexander Smith, who is kicked in the ear while his toes are trapped beneath his feet. The Woman in the Sun Hat, decades older now, snatches the Coin of Atlantis from Alex's pocket. It's noon, and snow drifts down in the middle of a mild breeze at dusk, with ten-foot mounds crashing across the sand. The two Italian bakers, who have Alex's toes trapped beneath his feet, hurl Alex across the beach toward the tent. As they pass a bundle of wooden crates, Alex uses the bakers as leverage to kick up his knees and snap open the latch on the rope ties that bind the crates together. Alex jabs his heels into the bakers' knees and sprints toward the Woman in the Sun Hat, who spots Alex approaching and scurries toward the ladder that leads up to the podium. Alex withstands the gust of snow swirling on the beach and moves his way to where Sun Hat is climbing the ladder. Alex grabs the coin back from Sun Hat, but a baker delivers a weak nudge to Alex's ear, sending the coin tumbling out of his grip and sliding across the sand.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The study is cluttered with books as Professor Henry Jones examines an ancient parchment, sketching a stained-glass image with Roman numerals. Indy closes the study door just as Herman enters playing a trumpet. Indy snatches it away, but Herman spits on Indy, indicating the sheriff's arrival. Indy presents the Cross to the sheriff, who casually passes it to Fedora. Fedora, with Roscoe, Rough Rider, and Halfbreed, is allied with the sheriff. Roscoe grabs the Cross and flees. Fedora respects Indy by placing his hat on Indy's head. As the brim lifts, an adult Indiana Jones is revealed, punched while restrained. The older Man in the Panama Hat retrieves the Cross from Indy during a stormy night at sea. With his arms pinned, Indy uses leverage against the sailors to break fuel drum clamps, allowing him to elbow free. He races toward Panama Hat, facing crashing waves, and reclaims the Cross, but a sailor hits Indy, making him drop it again.

lies open on the desk  The hat blocks Indy's face and the brim fills the screen  Indy reaches for the trumpet pulling it from Herman's mouth but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face  Roscoe reaches in takes it from Fedora and runs out the door  The Man in the Panama Hat years older now removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt  Fedora enters the house followed by Roscoe Rough Rider and Halfbreed and politely removes his hat holding it in his hand  As the brim tilts up we see the face of a fullgrown Indiana Jones who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back  Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck Indy shows the Cross more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point and the sheriff takes it casually  As they pass a bundle of fuel drums Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: He holds the hat by the crown and puts it on Indy's head a show of respect and admiration for the boy  The hat blocks Indy's face and the brim fills the screen  As the brim tilts up we see the face of a fullgrown Indiana Jones who is punched in the face while his arms are pinned behind his back  The Man in the Panama Hat years older now removes the Cross of Coronado from Indy's belt  It's night and rain pours down in the middle of a violent storm at sea with thirtyfoot waves crashing across the deck  The two Portuguese sailors who have Indy's arms pinned behind his back propel Indy across the deck toward the rail  As they pass a bundle of fuel drums Indy uses the sailors as leverage to kick up his feet and break open the clamp on the metal bands that hold the drums together  Indy jabs his elbows into the sailors' stomachs and rushes toward the Man in the Panama Hat who sees Indy coming and hurries toward the ladder that leads up to the bridge  Indy withstands the force of waves crashing on the deck and makes his way to where Panama Hat is climbing the ladder  Indy takes the cross back from Panama Hat but a sailor delivers a powerful blow to Indy's face sending the cross flying out of his grip and skittering across the deck The study is cluttered with books and Professor Henry Jones is absorbed at his desk studying a very ancient parchment volume that lies open on the desk  The page shows a beautifully illuminated picture of what might be a stainedglass window incorporating a series of Roman numerals  The Professor is not just studying it he is copying it into his own notebook sketching with his hand and holding up one finger  The study door is just closing Indy closing it behind him just as Herman comes through the front door still playing the trumpet  Indy reaches for the trumpet pulling it from Herman's mouth but Herman continues to spit right into Indy's face  Herman means the sheriff who now enters the house  Indy shows the Cross more or less handing it to the sheriff to make his point and the sheriff takes it casually  Fedora enters the house followed by Roscoe Rough Rider and Halfbreed and politely removes his hat holding it in his hand  The sheriff and Fedora are in cahoots and the sheriff hands the Cross to Fedora  Roscoe reaches in takes it from Fedora and runs out the door  Fedora remains behind for a moment turning and speaking to Indy in an ironic mantoman way
